title: What about $\sqrt[3]{2}$
description: What about $\sqrt[3]{2}$? Parity arguments don't work here. This requires algebraic number theory and the rational root theorem. (The multiplicity argument generalizes: if some prime has multiplicity not divisible by 3, the cube root is irrational.)

title: Are there irrational numbers that aren't roots of any polynomial
description: Are there irrational numbers that aren't roots of any polynomial? Yes—transcendental numbers like $\pi$ and $e$. Proving their irrationality is much harder.

title: Can this generalize to $\sqrt[n]{m}$
description: Can this generalize to $\sqrt[n]{m}$? Yes! $\sqrt[n]{m}$ is irrational iff $m$ is not a perfect $n$-th power.
